channel.title: Home on tntmath
channel.description: Recent content in Home on tntmath

item.title: Waco, Texas
item.description:
This website https://wacohistory.org/ is very interesting, containing many historical facts about Waco.

Things that people know when hearing about Waco:

  • “The Waco siege”. It was a standoff between a religioous cult and FBI near Waco, Texas, lasing from February 28, 1993 to April 19, 1993.

item.title: On Comparison Principle
item.description:
1. Comparison results for quasilinear equations in annular domains and applications, Francesca Da Lio, Communications in Partial Differential Equations 27(1&2)(1):283-323

  2. On the generalized Dirichlet problem for viscous Hamilton–Jacobi equations, Guy Barles, Francesca Da Lio, Journal de Mathématiques Pures et Appliquées Volume 83, Issue 1, January 2004, Pages 53-75

  3. Barles, G., Rouy, E., Souganidis, P.E. (1999). Remarks on the Dirichlet Problem for Quasilinear Elliptic and Parabolic Equations. In: McEneaney, W.M., Yin, G.G., Zhang, Q. (eds) Stochastic Analysis, Control, Optimization and Applications. Systems & Control: Foundations & Applications. Birkhäuser, Boston, MA. https://doi.org/10.1007/978-1-4612-1784-8_12

Let \( \Omega\subset \R^n \) [1]

References

item.title: Collection of Notes on Hamilton-Jacobi Equations
Perron Method - Notes and Remarks
item.description:
The Dirichlet problem on bounded domain

The basic problem takes the form of solving for an unknown function \( u:\overline{\Omega} \to \mathbb{R} \) where \( \Omega \) is an open, connected subset of \( \mathbb{R}^n \), the boundary value problem

$$ \begin{equation}\label{eq:PDE} \begin{cases} \begin{aligned} \Delta u &= 0 &&\text{in}\; \Omega, \\ u &= g &&\text{on}\; \partial\Omega \end{aligned} \end{cases} \end{equation} $$

where \( g:\partial \Omega \to \mathbb{R}\) is a given continuous function. The boundary value problem \(\eqref{eq:PDE}\) is extremely important and has a rich history of development, through

item.title: Collection of Notes
item.description:
A collection of resources gathered between 2022 and 2025.

  • Optimal transports
  • Hamilton-Jacobi equations
  • Miscellaneous
  • Machine Learning
  • Homogenization
  • PDEs
  • Functional Analysis
  • Fractional PDEs, free boundary problems, and related topics
  • Mean-field game and related papers
  • References

2025-07-19. (At Madison)

Some movies

  • It’s a Wonderful Life

Some PDEs papers, and notes on numerical analysis.

  • Mini course by Jean-Luc Thiffeault Differential Geometry In Continuum Mechanics

  • Stack Exchange Vague convergence VS Weak convergence of probability measure.

item.title: Another Note on A blogdown Tutorial
item.description: I just discovered an awesome tutorial on blogdown written by Alison. I have to admit this is the best blogdown tutorial I have seen so far.

item.title: A Quick Note on Two Beautiful Websites
item.description:
To me, the two most impressive websites based on blogdown are:

  1. Rob J Hyndman’s personal website.
  2. Live Free or Dichotomize by Lucy and Nick et al.

I’m sure there will be more.

item.title: About This Page
item.description: XMin is the first Hugo theme I have designed. The original reason that I wrote it was I needed a minimal example of Hugo themes when I was writing the blogdown book. Basically I wanted a simple theme that supports a navigation menu, a home page, other single pages, lists of pages, blog posts, categories, tags, and RSS. That is all. Nothing fancy. In terms of CSS and JavaScript, I really want to keep them minimal. In fact, this theme does not contain any JavaScript code at all, although on this example website I did introduce some JavaScript code (still relatively simple anyway). The theme does not contain any images, either, and is pretty much a plain-text theme.
